``` bash
git checkout trunk
git fetch https://github.com/apache/libcloud.git trunk:upstream
git merge upstream
```

I assume you branched this from #940? We should close that first.
this now needs to be rebased, thanks Sam
@tonybaloney How would you like me to modify error handling? Or what do you think is not clean enough?
Updated following @tonybaloney review.

@supertom This pull request is important for ansible now that ansible's `gce` module uses `ex_create_multiple_nodes` and provides the same parameters conditionally to both `create_node` and `ex_create_multiple_nodes` based on the `number` parameter. I recently tried to provision a cluster of preemptible nodes from ansible and libcloud notified me that `ex_preemptible` was not a supported parameter. I have tested the custom build of libcloud with this patch and it fixes the behavior I described in ansible in that use case.
@watermelo if you follow the steps in https://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development.html#contributing-bigger-changes you can complete the ICLA online.
@davidhalter if you haven't already, I need you to sign the ASF ICLA (an agreement for individual contributors) https://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development.html#contributing-bigger-changes

@tonybaloney 

I have signed it and I have also gotten confirmation:

> This message acknowledges receipt of your ICLA, which has been filed in the Apache Software Foundation records.
With this message, the Libcloud PMC has been notified that your ICLA has been filed.

@Kami Yes, that was me. :) You're very welcome. :+1:

`requests` explicitly does not support Python 3.2. https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/issues/3507
This PR will mean dropping 3.2 support.

@tonybaloney The documentation doesn't seem like it's up-to-date. Did we break the builds with this PR?

(AFAIK I was able to build the docs with this commit).

@davidhalter It looks like that for some reasons docs builds haven't been automatically triggered for a while now.

I manually triggered it for latest for now and I will look what is going on with automatically triggered builds.

The manually triggered build has finished and the provider is listed there now - https://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/latest/compute/supported_providers.html

I believe there were two issues.

1. Automatic build triggering has been broken for a while now (:sadface:) - c06497f17b83d3db2bb3f7f7b93317dcdbe47cdb
2. Table with link to the provider documentation has been broken. Just a heads up - this table is automatically generated using `./contrib/generate_provider_feature_matrix_table.py` script - e5fc049be73fb020ec33825dfd138c9e84379148

I believe both issues should be fixed now, but need to wait for the Travis and RTD build to finish :)

It looks like automatic docs build triggering is working again - https://travis-ci.org/apache/libcloud/jobs/188560819#L855 and provider matrix is also back again https://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/latest/supported_providers.html#provider-matrix :)

/cc @tonybaloney
@Kami what do you think? This PR is now done and everything is passing
download this package here- http://people.apache.org/~anthonyshaw/libcloud/1.5.0.post0/
@Kami Thanks! Is there any way to PR for the website as well? I wasn't able to find a repository of it.
@tonybaloney Maybe 2.0.0-rc1 and if everything is fine, call it 2.0.0?: :)

That package had a dumb error in it, I've since fixed it and against a live API (GoDaddy). I've tested the following scenarios 

- Applying a custom proxy via the environment variable
- Using libcloud.security to disable SSL verification
- Using libcloud.security to set a custom CA certificate
- Combining all of those scenarios
- Verification of custom headers applied by the driver using Charles Proxy and inspecting the HTTP messages manually
- Decoding JSON messages - although this still uses the existing methods, not the requests own json() decoder.

IMO, this is ready to merge. I would like to test the raw connections and file uploads if anyone has an account on one of those providers?
Tested `download_object` and `download_object_as_stream()` in the `GOOGLE_STORAGE` driver, which uses the S3 code. Both work.
`upload_object_as_stream` is complicated. I'm not sure the iterators are correctly handling the sessions or if the Google Storage API is just broken.

ok, figured it out. uploads don't work, because the current storage driver base code starts a `raw` connection session, sends the request and the headers but doesn't read the response from httplib, the callback (which could be one of 5 weird and crazy methods) then sends the data. 
`requests` does not support sending part of a request. So the options are:
* rewrite the storage driver base code to take advantage of `requests` native support for chunking via yield generators or passing a file stream object. http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/user/advanced/#streaming-uploads 
* use a "raw" httplib connection and use the old code. So requests is used for the non-storage APIs and httplib for the storage APIs.

I favour the first but it seems too much to change all in 1 go so for the sake of sanity and stability, option 2 would be the more logical choice. @Kami ?

Yeah, ideally we could do 1 (public API and behavior stays the same, just the implementation details change).

From a quick glance it looks like that by switching to requests we do lose some flexibility (like ability to specify chunk size, etc.), but I only done a quick glance so I could be wrong. It also looks like we might be able to simplify upload and download via stream methods a lot if we switch to requests so all those base class methods might not be needed anymore or at least we can simplify them.

In any case, I don't care much about the implementation detail as long as the API and all the behavior stays the same.
Ok. Download object as stream doesn't respond the correct type. I'll sort that out
@pquentin https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/923/commits/109ecad94257615b57f196f3c36d13d7b3c8e8fd should fix the download as stream iterator bug.

Frustratingly, the Storage mock system relies on the mocked http methods being in the response class. For the regular mocked http client, they belong to the connection class. For what I assume was a mistake, is now part of every unit test that requires a raw connection. So the tests are still broken but the code works fine!

With the latest changes, the HTTPS issues went away. Thanks! 💯 

I have an issue left with the download as stream method. Here's the relevant pytest output:

```
iterator = <bound method Response.iter_content of <Response [200]>>, chunk_size = 8096, fill_size = False, yield_empty = False

    def read_in_chunks(iterator, chunk_size=None, fill_size=False,
                       yield_empty=False):
        chunk_size = chunk_size or CHUNK_SIZE

        if isinstance(iterator, (file, httplib.HTTPResponse)):
            get_data = iterator.read
            args = (chunk_size, )
        else:
            get_data = next
            args = (iterator, )

        data = b('')
        empty = False

        while not empty or len(data) > 0:
            if not empty:
                try:
>                   chunk = b(get_data(*args))
E                   TypeError: 'method' object is not an iterator
```

Should I report such issues on JIRA now that the PR got merged?
@pquentin Can you gist the script you're using to test the download of a file?
@pquentin this is what I'm doing : https://gist.github.com/tonybaloney/e7159fbe72b81decce0395ceb87aa358

It's part of our integration tests. Until I can reduce this to a minimal script, all I can say is that I call `next()` on the iterator returned by `download_object_as_stream`.

PS: maybe your gist above can be made part of libcloud test suite?

Great idea!

If this is also extended to storage, maybe the test storage driver could be the local storage driver? It would need to support metadata, though, but that should not be too hard, either with xattr or a hidden folder containing JSON or pickle files with the metadata.

I also see that libcloud tests support plugging our own secrets, in theory this would allow to run real end-to-ends tests without mocks, right? That would be too slow for normal usage, but would allow to catch more issues. Can you please confirm that this is not what this issue is about?
